title: A Letter to the Burning Man Community from a Black Man
author: Guest Post
content:
Rob Smith, aka Black Rock Smitty, is a filmmaker from New York. He shared this perspective on social media and gave us his permission to repost it here. As always, we ask you to keep it kind and constructive in the comments. We will not tolerate hateful, racist or ignorant posts.

Greetings,

I hope youâ€™re well & safe during these unprecedented times in the world. With the current climate of police violence, race & racism, politics, & covid 19. Questions & actions have been taking place all over the country. Iâ€™ve seen posts and threads relating to all topics. But I have refrained from throwing my 2 cents in the pot. I canâ€™t tell you much or more than you already know about covid19, I can give you a fair conversation on politics. When it comes to police violence, race & racism, I could share my experiences from age 14 til now. But today I want to discuss race & racism on playa.

When my friends asked me whatâ€™s Burning Man like after my 1st journey home in 2018, I would reply that I canâ€™t exactly explain, itâ€™s just awesome & itâ€™s the ONLY place in the world Iâ€™ve ever been where hundreds if not thousands of white people told me â€˜ Welcome home, Iâ€™m so happy youâ€™re here!!â€™ Someone had to have slipped me some LSD on the Burner bus in to Black Rock City for this to be real. Donâ€™t get it twisted, Iâ€™ve been in the film industry for 25 years. Iâ€™ve probably got more White, European, Asian, & Hispanic friends than a lot of Burners have black friends. But the energy, the vibe, the frequency of Black Rock City is unlike any other. Iâ€™ve only had 2 Burns so far & I was so looking forward to this yearâ€™s Burn. Itâ€™s become my happy place, my peace, my sanctuary away from the default world & the prejudices of society, that for me have been going on all my life, & now in these times everyoneâ€™s seeing what weâ€™ve lived.

Iâ€™ve seen discussions on things that can be done to help the Black community & diversifying Burning Man. With these discussions there are moments, when Iâ€™m reading through a thread where I feel like a charity case. The Burner community is large & dominantly white as we all know. So when you have these discussions in an open forum; youâ€™re talking â€œabout usâ€â€¦ as opposed to â€œto usâ€ and It feels wrong. We might not have large numbers yet at the Burn but we are here. We are present. You can talk to us, we would love it. We welcome it.

We can answer some questions such as â€œdo black people camp?â€ And just like white people or other ethnicitiesâ€¦some do & some donâ€™t. You canâ€™t tell me every single white person in the world camps. Stop it, thatâ€™s nonsense. But â€œdo they like EDM musicâ€, or techno, or house, or anything that isnâ€™t hip-hop (yaâ€™ll call it rap). But again just like white people & other ethnicitiesâ€¦some do & some donâ€™t. And letâ€™s be honest hereâ€¦ anybody that parties & gets fucked up like Burners is gonna dance to whatever the fuck is coming out of the speakers. Shit, some of you probably canâ€™t stand any of it sober & what are a lot of you listening to when youâ€™re not at the Burnâ€¦ Jay-Z, Biggie, Beyonce, Drake, Kanye? So whatâ€™s the difference there? We can get down to damn near every type of music & make it look good. Wait, except for Metal â€” that shit looks dangerous. Oh, but â€œcan they afford it? Is it too expensive?â€ I spend roughly around $3K each of the 2 times Iâ€™ve attended, coming from NY. But I know people in the hood or ghetto that arenâ€™t drug dealers that spend that kind of money on a belt, sneakers, & a night at the strip club. (I know, I know.) We can be resourceful, focused, & have great resolve when we want to do something or go somewhere. And worst case thatâ€™s what low-income tickets are for. Cause if all the white & other non POC are rich or well off, who the fuck is buying all the low-income tickets? Not the black people! Maybe some of us, but not all of us. So whatâ€™s the difference there?

Thereâ€™s no real differences between any of us in any of the above mentioned scenarios except for perceptions & stereotypes. Stop that shit. Donâ€™t put us in a box, weâ€™re human beings just like you. We like adventure, we like art, we like yoga, we like the sun. (I havenâ€™t touched a bottle of sunscreen ever on the playa â€” top that!! ) We like beer & liquor, we like dope sunrises with omelets, we like yoga & seminars, we like riding our bikes, we like funky, cool, wardrobe & outfits. Come on, some of you have seen my Black Rock Smitty vest! Itâ€™s hard, itâ€™s cool. A lot of you thought I was a veteran Burner my 1st year because of the vest. Cause the vest says I belong here, I had it made because I wanted to be here & I knew I belonged in Black Rock City.

Ok, now thatâ€™s all out the way. When it comes to Black people & POC, from what Iâ€™ve talked about with my people in real life & on social media, a great deal of them have never heard of Burning Man. Working in the film industry, Iâ€™ve asked some celebrity POC artists if theyâ€™ve been to Burning Man & the reply is, â€œNah, whatâ€™s that.â€ And itâ€™s the same question from my everyday friends & family, my social media followers (6k might not be a lot to some of you, but itâ€™s more Black people than you know hmph) when I started posting Iâ€™m going to Burning Man on my Instagram. â€œWhatâ€™s that?â€ When I describe it, the repliesâ€¦ â€œNever heard of it, sounds like some white people shit.â€ Followed by â€œYou make it sound amazing, I think I wanna go.â€ So that makes me wonderâ€¦.if thereâ€™s no real advertising about it (at least not in urban circles or communities), the only way we would know about it would be from word of mouth, or someone who attends inviting us. I found it on my own & made it my mission to get here & Iâ€™m not rich. Iâ€™ve only been 2 times and I have about 10-20 people if not more interested & ready to make the journey home. And thatâ€™s just me. Iâ€™m sure other POC Burners might have the same responses. If the Burn contains what, around 80,000 people & thereâ€™s only an estimated 300 plus POC attending. Some who have found their own way to the playa, some invited by the aforementioned person, & the rest invited by non POC or white people. Remember no known advertising so that leaves 3 possible scenarios.

Iâ€™m doing my part, Iâ€™m spreading the word. But donâ€™t worry, I know the Burn isnâ€™t for everybody for various reasons. So Iâ€™m a bit selective in who I would bring into the vibe, cause I donâ€™t want my trip home to be fucked up in any capacity. Like the friend someone brought that got too drunk or too high (wait, whatâ€™s that matter at the Burn duh) or the friend who tried to fight, or harassed a woman or a man. I know those things have happened. Iâ€™ve heard the stories & Iâ€™ve seen the scenarios. I wouldnâ€™t bring that to the dope ass camp Iâ€™ve been with the last 2 Burns, Ashram Galactica. Iâ€™m one of the handful of POC at the camp & the core family has embraced me & shown me nothing but kindness, care, & love since day one. But let me keep it a buck ( ğŸ’¯). If youâ€™re not up on urban slang that just means Iâ€™m about to be really honest. You ready.

As amazing & as wonderful as Burning Man is, Black Rock City is not completely exempt from some of the racial prejudices of the default world. For the most part Iâ€™d say the vast majority of my interactions are awesome. But Iâ€™ve also had people not acknowledge my greeting them. Iâ€™ve seen people look at me whisper & turn away. Overall it doesnâ€™t bother me, the default world prepared me for that a long time ago. And with 80,000 people there, the odds are good that some wonâ€™t completely embrace the concept of radical inclusion. And stereotypesâ€¦.oh boy. My camp is awesome & the Gilded Lily Bar is in my humble opinionâ€¦ one of the best bars on playa. Shout out to Jamie Mac. I usually enjoy the party there until midnight or a little after, before I head out into the night. But when Iâ€™m there you can usually find me right at the entrance greeting people. And for some reason (stereotypes) on occasions people talk to me & then wait for me to grant them admission into the bar. I AM NOT THE BOUNCER OR SECURITY! Some of my camp mates think I should get a rubber stamp that says Iâ€™M NOT THE BOUNCER. Youâ€™ll find out if we did it next year.

Closing out â€” sorry for the long read (if youâ€™ve gotten this far) â€” Radical Inclusion, right..?

Once any of the black Burners bought a ticket to Burning Manâ€¦that was Radical Inclusion. Once any of the black Burners rolled thru the gateâ€¦that was Radical Inclusion. We are here, we are present, talk to us, engage with usâ€¦ We are human beings. Pitstop at that camp with a lot of black or POC people. Drink with us, dance with us, laugh with us cause weâ€™re fucking funny. In the default world many of us have to be the ones to break the ice, start the convo, or make you comfortable with our presence. If you feel intimidated or timid about approaching a black person on playa, imagine being black & rolling up to camp with 20 white people outside and saying hi. That should not be the case at Black Rock City. We are here and we are Burners that just happen to be black â€” radically include us & your friends in the default. And if you donâ€™t have any black or POC friends in the default, get some, itâ€™s time.

Sincerely,

Rob Smith / Black Rock Smitty
